title: How to Use GitHub Actions Without Exposing Your Code
text:
GitHub Actions has become the go-to tool for automating workflows‚Äîwhether you‚Äôre running tests, building reports, or deploying applications. It‚Äôs powerful, integrated, and for public repositories, completely free.
But here‚Äôs the catch:
GitHub Actions free tier only works for public repositories.
If your repository is private, you‚Äôre limited to about 2,000 minutes per month on the Free plan. Public repositories? Unlimited minutes. The same applies to GitHub Pages‚Äîdeploying a website from a public repo is free, but deploying from a private repo requires upgrading your account.
So what do you do when your code contains:

Proprietary algorithms?
Client data that can‚Äôt be exposed?
Research methods not ready for publication?
API keys or sensitive configurations?

Most people think they have two choices:

Make the repository public (and risk exposing everything)
Pay for private repo minutes

But there‚Äôs a third way‚Äîand it‚Äôs smarter than both.

title: How to Use GitHub Actions Without Exposing Your Code
section: The Solution: Public Workflow, Private Code
text:
The Solution: Public Workflow, Private Code
Here‚Äôs the key insight: Your workflow configuration doesn‚Äôt need to live in the same repository as your code.
You can create a public repository that hosts only your GitHub Actions workflows, while your actual code stays locked in a private repository. The two communicate securely using Personal Access Tokens (PATs).

Why This Works
‚úÖ Your proprietary code stays private
‚úÖ You get unlimited free GitHub Actions minutes
‚úÖ You can showcase your automation process
‚úÖ Outputs (reports, dashboards) can be published without exposing source code
‚úÖ Perfect for reproducible research where methods are confidential but results should be shared

title: How to Use GitHub Actions Without Exposing Your Code
text:
Real-World Example: Automated Weekly Reports
Let me show you how this works with a concrete scenario.

The Challenge
A healthcare organization needed weekly automated reports. The workflow required:

Connecting to a secure database (private credentials)
Running R-based data transformations (proprietary algorithms)
Generating a Quarto report
Publishing the final HTML to a public website

The problem: All code had to remain private, yet automation was needed every Monday morning‚Äîwithout exceeding free GitHub limits.


The Solution
Private Repository: client-health-pipeline

Contains: R scripts, data transformations, credentials
Status: Fully private

Public Repository: automated-reporting

Contains: Only the .github/workflows/ folder
Status: Public (to access unlimited free minutes)
Purpose: Triggers automation, connects securely to private repo, publishes results



The Outcome
‚úÖ Private code remains protected
‚úÖ Reports generate and publish automatically
‚úÖ Zero additional GitHub costs
‚úÖ Workflow transparency maintained
This approach works for automated reports, R package testing, ETL jobs, Shiny app deployment, and reproducible research‚Äîcombining security, automation, and cost efficiency.

title: How to Use GitHub Actions Without Exposing Your Code
text:
Step-by-Step Implementation

Step 1: Create Your Private Repository
This is where your actual work lives.
# Create a new private repository on GitHub
# Name it: my-private-analysis
# Initialize with a .gitignore
What goes here:

All your source code
Data processing scripts
Configuration files
Any sensitive information

Critical: Add a .gitignore file:
# Credentials and secrets
.env
.Renviron
config.yml
*.key

# Data files
data/raw/*
*.csv
*.xlsx

# Outputs
output/*
cache/*


Step 2: Create Your Public Workflow Repository
This repository will be public and contain only automation logic.
# Create a new PUBLIC repository
# Name it: automated-workflows
What goes here:

.github/workflows/ folder with your YAML files
Optional: README explaining your automation approach
Optional: Sample scripts (no sensitive code)



Step 3: Generate a Personal Access Token (PAT)
Your public workflow needs permission to access your private repository.

Go to GitHub Settings ‚Üí Developer settings ‚Üí Personal access tokens ‚Üí Tokens (classic)
Click ‚ÄúGenerate new token (classic)‚Äù
Name it: workflow-private-repo-access
Set expiration: 90 days (for security)
Select scopes: ‚úÖ repo (full control of private repositories)
Click ‚ÄúGenerate token‚Äù
Copy the token immediately (you won‚Äôt see it again!)



Step 4: Add the Token as a Secret
In your public workflow repository:

Go to Settings ‚Üí Secrets and variables ‚Üí Actions
Click ‚ÄúNew repository secret‚Äù
Name: PERSONAL_ACCESS_TOKEN
Value: Paste your PAT from Step 3
Click ‚ÄúAdd secret‚Äù

Security note: Secrets are encrypted and automatically redacted from logs.


Step 5: Create Your Workflow
In your public repository, create .github/workflows/automated-report.yml:
name: Weekly Report Generation

on:
  schedule:
    - cron: '0 6 * * 1'  # Every Monday at 6 AM UTC
  workflow_dispatch:      # Allows manual trigger

jobs:
  generate-report:
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
    
    steps:
      - name: Checkout private code
        uses: actions/checkout@v4
        with:
          repository: yourusername/my-private-analysis
          token: ${{ secrets.PERSONAL_ACCESS_TOKEN }}
          path: private-code
      
      - name: Setup R
        uses: r-lib/actions/setup-r@v2
        with:
          r-version: '4.3.0'
      
      - name: Install R packages
        run: |
          cd private-code
          Rscript -e 'install.packages(c("tidyverse", "purrr"))'
      
      - name: Run analysis
        run: |
          cd private-code
          Rscript analysis.R
      
      - name: Render Quarto report
        run: |
          cd private-code
          quarto render report.qmd
      
      - name: Upload report
        uses: actions/upload-artifact@v4
        with:
          name: weekly-report
          path: private-code/output/report.html
      
      - name: Deploy to GitHub Pages
        uses: peaceiris/actions-gh-pages@v3
        with:
          github_token: ${{ secrets.GITHUB_TOKEN }}
          publish_dir: private-code/output


Step 6: Test Your Workflow

Go to the Actions tab in your public repository
Select your workflow
Click ‚ÄúRun workflow‚Äù (manual trigger)
Monitor the execution logs
Security check: Ensure no secrets appear in logs

title: How to Use GitHub Actions Without Exposing Your Code
text:
Other Powerful Use Cases

Automated Testing for Private R Packages
Run R CMD check on every commit without exposing source code:
name: R Package Check
on: [push, pull_request]
jobs:
  check:
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
    steps:
      - uses: actions/checkout@v4
        with:
          repository: yourname/private-r-package
          token: ${{ secrets.PERSONAL_ACCESS_TOKEN }}
      - uses: r-lib/actions/setup-r@v2
      - run: R CMD check .


Scheduled Data Pipeline Execution
Run ETL jobs daily without manual intervention:
on:
  schedule:
    - cron: '0 2 * * *'  # 2 AM daily
jobs:
  etl:
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
    steps:
      - name: Run data pipeline
        run: python etl_pipeline.py


Reproducible Research Workflows
Generate manuscript outputs while keeping methods confidential:
- name: Render manuscript
  run: quarto render manuscript.qmd
- name: Publish results only
  uses: actions/upload-artifact@v4
  with:
    name: published-paper
    path: output/manuscript.pdf


Shiny App Deployment
Deploy Shiny apps from private code to public servers:
- name: Deploy to shinyapps.io
  env:
    SHINYAPPS_TOKEN: ${{ secrets.SHINYAPPS_TOKEN }}
  run: |
    Rscript -e 'rsconnect::deployApp()'

title: How to Use GitHub Actions Without Exposing Your Code
text:
Common Issues & Solutions

‚ÄúAuthentication Failed‚Äù Error
Cause: PAT doesn‚Äôt have right permissions or expired.
Solution:

Check token expiration
Regenerate with repo scope
Update secret in repository settings



‚ÄúResource not accessible by integration‚Äù
Cause: GITHUB_TOKEN can‚Äôt access private repos.
Solution: Always use PERSONAL_ACCESS_TOKEN for private repo access, not the default GITHUB_TOKEN.


Secrets Appearing in Logs
Cause: Accidental print of sensitive variables.
Solution:
- name: Debug (safe)
  run: |
    echo "Workflow running..."
    # NEVER: echo ${{ secrets.PERSONAL_ACCESS_TOKEN }}

title: Stop Manual Updates: Automate Your Web Content with YAML and Quarto
text:
Understanding the Building Blocks

What is YAML?
YAML (YAML Ain‚Äôt Markup Language) is a human-friendly data format. Think of it as a structured way to write information that both humans and computers can read easily.
Here‚Äôs a simple example:
person:
  name: Sarah Johnson
  age: 32
  skills:
    - Python
    - Data Analysis
    - Leadership
Why YAML?

Easy to read and write (no weird syntax)
Supports nested structures (data within data)
Perfect for configuration and content files
Non-technical people can update it confidently



What is Quarto?
Quarto is a scientific and technical publishing system. It takes your content (written in Markdown) and code (R, Python, etc.) and creates beautiful outputs: websites, reports, presentations, and more.
Think of Quarto as a translator: You write in a simple format, and it generates professional-looking HTML, PDF, or Word documents.

title: Stop Manual Updates: Automate Your Web Content with YAML and Quarto
section: Step-by-Step Tutorial: Building an Automated Team Directory
text:
Step-by-Step Tutorial: Building an Automated Team Directory
Let‚Äôs build a real example together. We‚Äôll create a team directory that automatically updates when you modify a YAML file.

Step 1: Create Your Data File (YAML)
Create a file called team_members.yml:
team_members:
  - name: "Sarah Johnson"
    role: "Data Scientist"
    department: "Analytics"
    email: "sarah.johnson@company.com"
    linkedin: "https://linkedin.com/in/sarahjohnson"
    bio: "Specialized in machine learning and predictive analytics."
    skills:
      - "Python"
      - "R"
      - "Machine Learning"
      - "SQL"
    joined_date: "2020-03-15"
    
  - name: "Marcus Chen"
    role: "Senior Developer"
    department: "Engineering"
    email: "marcus.chen@company.com"
    linkedin: "https://linkedin.com/in/marcuschen"
    bio: "Full-stack developer passionate about building scalable applications."
    skills:
      - "JavaScript"
      - "Python"
      - "Docker"
      - "AWS"
    joined_date: "2019-07-22"
What‚Äôs happening here?

team_members: is the main container
Each - starts a new team member
Indentation shows which data belongs to whom
Skills are a list (multiple items per person)



Step 2: Create Your Quarto Document (QMD)
Create a file called team.qmd:
```{r}
---
title: "Our Team"
format: html
---

# Load the data
library(yaml)
library(dplyr)

team_data <- yaml::read_yaml("team_members.yml")
team_members <- team_data$team_members

# Create HTML for each team member
for (member in team_members) {
  cat("##", member$name, "\n\n")
  cat("**", member$role, "** |", member$department, "\n\n")
  cat(member$bio, "\n\n")
  cat("üìß", member$email, "\n\n")
  cat("---\n\n")
}
```


Step 3: Render Your Page
In your terminal or RStudio:
quarto render team.qmd
You now have a team.html file with all your team members beautifully formatted !

title: Stop Manual Updates: Automate Your Web Content with YAML and Quarto
text:
Common Pitfalls and Solutions

Pitfall 1: Indentation Errors
Problem: YAML is sensitive to indentation. Solution: Use 2 spaces consistently. Most editors can show whitespace.


Pitfall 2: Special Characters
Problem: Colons and quotes in text can break parsing. Solution: Wrap text in quotes: title: "Workshop: Advanced Topics"


Pitfall 3: Missing Files
Problem: Quarto can‚Äôt find the YAML file. Solution: Ensure both files are in the same directory or use full paths.

Taking It Further

Integration with Version Control
Store your YAML files in Git. Now you have: - Full history of changes - Collaboration with team members - Rollback capability if needed - Automated deployment triggers


Automation with GitHub Actions
Set up GitHub Actions to automatically rebuild your site when you push changes to the YAML file:
name: Render Site
on:
  push:
    paths:
      - '**.yml'
      - '**.qmd'
jobs:
  render:
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
    steps:
      - uses: actions/checkout@v2
      - uses: quarto-dev/quarto-actions/setup@v2
      - run: quarto render
Now your site updates automatically on every commit!

title: From RStudio to Published Paper: Writing Manuscripts with Quarto
text:
TipWhat You‚Äôll Learn



By the end of this post, you‚Äôll know how to write an entire research paper inside RStudio - complete with live code, auto-generated figures, formatted references, and multiple output formats (Word, PDF, HTML)- all from a single source file.
Time to read: ~8 minutes




If you‚Äôre a researcher using R and RStudio, you probably spend hours there every day: cleaning data, running analyses, creating visualizations, and building statistical models.
But then comes the hard part: writing the actual paper.
Suddenly, you‚Äôre juggling

Exporting figures to PNG files
Copy-pasting results into Word
Managing citations in Zotero or Mendeley
Updating figures when your data changes (again!)
Dealing with formatting chaos before journal submission

What if you could skip all of that?
With Quarto, your entire manuscript lives in RStudio alongside your code. When you update your analysis, your paper updates too‚Äîautomatically. No more switching between tools. No more broken workflows.



Think of Quarto as the next generation of R Markdown, but supercharged:
‚úÖ Works with R, Python, Julia, and Observable
‚úÖ Creates Word docs, PDFs, HTML pages, and even journal-ready formats
‚úÖ Handles citations, cross-references, and figure numbering automatically
‚úÖ Already built into modern versions of RStudio (no extra installation needed!)
It‚Äôs designed for exactly what you‚Äôre trying to do: turn your research into a publication-ready document.






Note



New to R Markdown? Don‚Äôt worry! Quarto is beginner-friendly. If you can write in Word and copy-paste code, you can write with Quarto.





Let‚Äôs create a manuscript project in RStudio. It takes about 30 seconds:



In RStudio, go to: File ‚Üí New Project
Choose: New Directory ‚Üí Quarto Manuscript
Name your project (e.g., my-paper)
Click Create Project

RStudio creates a complete manuscript structure for you:
my-paper/
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ index.qmd          # Your main manuscript file (text + code)
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ references.bib     # Bibliography file (citations go here)
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ _quarto.yml        # Project settings (formats, styles, etc.)
‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ my-paper.Rproj     # RStudio project file



Open index.qmd and click Render. You‚Äôll see a beautifully formatted manuscript with:

Title and author information
Sections (Introduction, Methods, Results, etc.)
Example code chunks
Auto-generated bibliography

That‚Äôs it! You now have a working manuscript template.






Tipüí° Prefer to Start with a Complete Example?





I‚Äôve created a ready-to-use template with a demo research paper example (including plots, tables, and references).
Download: quarto-manuscript-demo on GitHub
Just download, open in RStudio, and click Render. Follow the README for required instructions.







The index.qmd file is where your paper lives. Here‚Äôs what a simple manuscript looks like:






NoteClick to view complete example manuscript code





---
title: "Impact of Exercise on Sleep Quality"
author: "Your Name"
date: "2025-10-03"
format:
  html: default
  docx: default
  pdf: default
bibliography: references.bib
---

## Abstract

We investigated the relationship between exercise frequency and sleep quality in 200 participants over 12 weeks.

## Introduction

Sleep disorders affect millions of people worldwide [@smith2020]. 
Recent evidence suggests physical activity may improve sleep outcomes...

## Methods

### Data Collection

We recruited participants aged 25-65 and tracked their exercise habits using wearable devices.


::: {.cell}

:::


## Results

As shown in Figure 1, we found a positive correlation between exercise and sleep quality (r = 0.45, p < 0.001).

## References






YAML Header (the --- section at top): Contains your paper‚Äôs metadata
Markdown Sections: Use ## for main sections, ### for subsections
Code Chunks: Wrapped in ```{r} ... ``` ‚Äî runs when you render
Citations: Use [@smith2020] to cite references from your .bib file
Figure Labels: #| label: fig-name creates numbered, cross-referenceable figures







Important



Tip: Use echo: false in code chunks to hide the code and show only the output. Perfect for final manuscripts!






One of the biggest pain points in academic writing is citation management. Quarto makes it surprisingly simple.



Create a .bib file (already done if you used the template!)
Add references in BibTeX format
Cite them in your text using [@citationkey]
Render ‚Üí Quarto generates a formatted bibliography automatically




In references.bib:
@article{smith2020,
  title={The Science of Sleep and Exercise},
  author={Smith, Jane and Johnson, Mark},
  journal={Journal of Health Research},
  year={2020},
  volume={15},
  pages={234-245}
}
In your manuscript:
Recent research shows strong correlations [@smith2020].

Editing too early wastes time and fuels procrastination.

Save grammar, clarity, and formatting for later rounds.

Structure first: Outline using your target journal‚Äôs template.

Write key sections first (Methods, Results).

Intro/Abstract last: they‚Äôll be sharper once your content is final.

Draft fast: Aim for 1 section/day. Quarto‚Äôs dynamic formatting/code tools remove friction.

Revise after drafting: Polishing a full draft is faster and more motivating than fixing fragments.

title: A Quick and Safe Way to Share Quarto Reports with Restricted Users
text:
Sometimes you need to share your updated reports with a restricted group of people instead of publishing them openly. A practical and secure way is to automate sending your reports by email. With Quarto and R, you can render your reports, attach them as PDF or HTML, and deliver them directly to your recipients‚Äô inboxes.
In this post, I will show you how to achieve this with R and Quarto, using Gmail as an example.



To allow R to send emails from your Gmail account, you must create a Gmail App Password. This is safer than using your main password.

Enable 2-Step Verification in your Google Account Security settings.

Go to the App Passwords page.
Choose the app and device (e.g., Mail ‚Üí Other ‚Üí ‚ÄúR script‚Äù).
Click Generate. Google will display a 16-character password.
Copy and save this password immediately, as it cannot be viewed again later.

This password is what you will use in your R script instead of your usual Gmail password.



Below is a complete R script that renders your Quarto report (report.qmd), produces PDF and HTML versions, and sends them as email attachments. You only need to replace the email addresses and the Gmail App Password.

# --- Load packages ---
library(quarto)
library(blastula)

# --- Step 1: Render your Quarto report into PDF and HTML ---
quarto_render("report.qmd", output_format = "pdf")
quarto_render("report.qmd", output_format = "html")

# --- Step 2: Create the email body ---
email <- compose_email(
  body = md("
  Hello,  

  The updated Quarto report is ready.  
  Please find both PDF and HTML versions attached.  

  Best regards,  
  Islem
  ")
)

# --- Step 3: Attach the reports ---
email <- add_attachment(email, file = "report.pdf")
email <- add_attachment(email, file = "report.html")

# --- Step 4: Send the email ---
smtp_send(
  email,
  from = "your_email@gmail.com",
  to = c("recipient1@example.com", "recipient2@example.com"),
  subject = paste0("Updated Report - ", Sys.Date()),
  credentials = creds(
    host = "smtp.gmail.com",
    port = 587,
    user = "your_email@gmail.com",
    use_ssl = TRUE
  )
)
# The app password will be requested interactively in a popup after running, no need to hard-code it




To make this fully automated:

On Windows, schedule the script with taskscheduleR.
On Linux/macOS, use cronR or add it to your system cron jobs.
Every time the script runs, your Quarto report will be rendered and sent to the selected users automatically.




Email automation is not the only way to share Quarto reports with restricted users:

Netlify with password protection: host your Quarto site and restrict access with a password.
GitHub Actions or GitLab CI: automate report rendering and emailing or publishing.
Posit Connect: enterprise solution that provides user access control, scheduling, and automatic email notifications out of the box.

Choose the approach that best fits your context and your audience‚Äôs needs.



For many small teams or individuals, automating email delivery is a quick, safe, and effective way to share Quarto reports with a limited group of users. By combining Quarto, R, and the blastula package, you can render, attach, and distribute updated reports with minimal effort.
